column4: How do I obtain the signing key used for a package, prior to running "apt-get install <package>", so that the key can be registered before doing the install?
which repository?
I don't know. Is there a generic way of finding out the key?
I know the package name.
Is it important to find out the repository name?
usually it's "trying to install" followed by "missing key 1234567890ABCDEF" followed by "gpg --recv-keys 90ABCDEF && gpg --export --armor 90ABCDEF | sudo apt-key add -"
yes, I saw many suggestions to that effect while searching Google for the past few hours on this subject.
unfortunately I don't have the key.
gpg --recb-key downloads it
yes, once I know the key, but I don't know the key.
apt-get will tell you
Good, How does apt-get tell me?
apt-get didn't tell me, when I attempted to install the package.
it will tell you when you do apt-get update
W: GPG error: http://seveas.ubuntulinux.nl dapper-seveas Release: The following signatures couldn't be verified because the public key is not available: NO_PUBKEY 49A120FD1135D466
something like that
I don't quite follow. I wish to install a new package. So how is apt-get update going to help?
well, that package is in a repository...
if you simply have a .deb you cannot get missing key errors
yes, it is in a repository.
so do apt-get update, look at the gpg error, and add the key....
Oh! I see! I've done "apt-get update" and now the packing is installing without authentication errors.
Thanks for you help.
